newsitem.title: GERMANY: TENNIS-AGASSI FACES "ULTIMATE TEST" AGAINST SAMPRAS.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-AGASSI FACES "ULTIMATE TEST" AGAINST SAMPRAS.

text.p: Andre Agassi's bid to qualify for next month's tennis world championship stepped up a gear on Thursday when he booked a mouth-watering quarter-final showdown with Pete Sampras in the Stuttgart Open.
Agassi, currently ninth in the world, needs to improve his ranking by one place to compete in the prestigious season-ending championship in Hanover.

The former world number one boosted his chances with a comfortable 6-4 6-2 third-round victory over compatriot Richey Reneberg to earn a clash with Sampras who swept aside promising Spaniard Felix Mantilla 6-1 6-4.
In recent months the pair have had television viewers glued to their sets with some intriguing matches played in London's Trafalgar Square and on an American downtown street.
But these were only commercials, whereas Friday's clash will be the real thing.
"It is the ultimate challenge in tennis to beat Sampras," Agassi said. "We are meeting a little earlier than we usually do but I hope it is a great match and we walk off the court feeling good."
Sampras added: "It is always a bit different when I see him across the net. He is one of the best players on the Tour. When he gets going he is tough to play. He is very dangerous."
Agassi, at one stage top of the rankings early in the year, has 2,292 points, 111 behind eighth-placed South African Wayne Ferreira.
Sampras is sure of making it to Hanover but is looking to confirm his leading position in the sport by finishing the year at the top of the rankings.
Sampras, 25, and Agassi, 26, have clashed in three major grand slam finals -- the last in 1995 when Sampras won the U.S. Open in four sets.

Their first top-class professional meeting took place in Rome on clay in 1989 when Agassi won easily 6-2 6-1. But just over a year later Sampras beat Agassi in the U.S. Open final to become the youngest men's champion ever at 19.
Agassi defeated three-times Wimbledon champion Sampras to win last year's Australian Open final but his rival leads their head-to-head statistics 10-8.

World number six Boris Becker, another player needing good results to make sure of a place at the world championship, looked in impressive form in the third round with a 6-4 7-5 victory over Swede Thomas Enqvist which took just 80 minutes.
Becker, who is trying to get back to his best after suffering a serious wrist injury at this year's Wimbledon, said it was one of his best performances for months.
"That was my best match since Wimbledon," the three-times Wimbledon champion said. "It shows I have broken through the problems with the wrist...I surprised myself how well I played."
In the quarter-finals Becker faces Swede Magnus Gustafsson who beat Australian Mark Woodforde 6-7 6-2 7-6. Dutchman Jan Siemerink faces big-serving Goran Ivanisevic in another quarter-final.
